analyzed: atra tāḥ iti strī liṅga nirdeśāt audumbaryaḥ iti bhāṣyāt ca śalākāsu kuśa śabdasya strī tvam mantavyam darbha viṣayasya na strī tvam  astrī kuśam iti anuśāsanāt
translated: Because of the rule kusha is not feminine.

analyzed: chandaḥ dṛṣṭāntam vyācaṣṭe yathā ca iti
translated: He explains the example of the meter, saying And just as.

original: navākṣarāṇi chandāṃsi āsurāṇyanyāni daivāni teṣāṃ kvacchindobhiḥ stuvata ityatrāviśeṣaprāptau paiṅgivākyādviśeṣagraha ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: nava akṣarāṇi chandāṃsi āsurāṇi anyāni daivāni teṣām kvacchindobhiḥ stuvate iti atra aviśeṣa prāptau paiṅgi vākyāt viśeṣa grahaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meters consisting of nine syllables belong to the asuras, the others to the gods. When it is said They praise with the meters, when there is a general application, the specific grasping is by the statement of Pingala. This is the meaning.

analyzed: stutim vivṛṇoti yathā iti
translated: He explains the praise, saying Just as.

original: ātirātre ṣoḍaśino grahasyāṅgabhūtaṃ stotraṃ kadeti chandogādīnāmākāṅkṣāyāmudayasamayāviṣṭe sūrye ṣoḍaśinaḥ stotramityārcaśruteḥ kālaviśeṣagraha
analyzed: ā atirātre ṣoḍaśinaḥ grahasya aṅga bhūtam stotram kadā iti chandoga ādīnām ākāṅkṣāyām udaya samaya āviṣṭe sūrye ṣoḍaśinaḥ stotram iti ārca śruteḥ kāla viśeṣa graha
translated: When there is a desire of the Chandogas and others as to when the praise which is a part of the Soma cup of the Shodashin is to be performed at the Atiratra sacrifice, by the Vedic statement The praise of the Shodashin is when the sun is at the time of rising, there is the grasping of a specific time.

analyzed: iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: ṛcaḥ dhīyate iti ārcāḥ
translated: The Chandogas are those who study the Rg verses.

analyzed: upagānam vibhajate yathā iti
translated: He divides the Upasana, saying Just as.

original: 'ṛtvija upagāyanti'ityaviśeṣaśruteḥ 'nādhvaryurūpagāyati'iti śrutyantarādadhvaryubhinnā ṛtvija upagāyantīti viśeṣagraha ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: ṛtvijaḥ upagāyanti iti aviśeṣa śruteḥ na adhvaryuḥ ūpagāyati iti śruti antarāt adhvaryu bhinnāḥ ṛtvijaḥ upagāyanti iti viśeṣa grahaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: When there is the Vedic statement The priests sing the Upasana, and the Vedic statement The Adhvaryu does not sing the Upasana, the meaning is that the specific grasping is that the priests other than the Adhvaryu sing the Upasana.

analyzed: nanu kuśa ādi vākyānām api kim iti viśeṣa śruti antara eka vākya tā abhyupagamyate
translated: But why should the statements about Kuśa grass etc. also be accepted as forming a single sentence with another specific Vedic text?

original: tatrāhaśrutyantarakṛtaṃ hīti /🔽sāmānyaviśeṣayorekavākyatārūpāyāṃ gatau satyāṃ vākyabhedaṃ kṛtvā nādhvaryuriti niṣedhādaviśeṣaśruteścādhvaryurupagāyati nopagāyati cetyevaṃ
analyzed: tatra āha śruti antara kṛtam hi iti  sāmānya viśeṣayoḥ eka vākya tā rūpāyām gatau satyām vākya bhedam kṛtvā na adhvaryuḥ iti niṣedhāt aviśeṣa śruteḥ ca adhvaryuḥ upagāyati na upagāyati ca iti evam
translated: To this he says: For the connection is made by another Vedic text.

analyzed: sarvatra vikalpaḥ na yuktaḥ
translated: When there is a connection in the form of a single sentence between the general and the specific, then, having made a division of the sentence due to the prohibition the Adhvaryu should not sing and due to the non-specific Vedic text, it is not proper to have an option everywhere in the form the Adhvaryu sings or does not sing.

analyzed: vrīhi yavayoḥ tu agatyā vikalpaḥ āśritaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the option regarding rice and barley is accepted only out of necessity.

analyzed: vikalpasya anyāyya tvam aṣṭa doṣa duṣṭa tvāt
translated: An option is improper because it is tainted with eight faults.

analyzed: tathā hi yadi vrīhi vākyam āśrīyate tadā yava vākyasya iṣṭa prāmāṇya tyāgaḥ
translated: Thus, if the statement about rice is accepted, then the statement about barley would abandon the accepted validity.
It would accept the undesired invalidity.

analyzed: kadācid yava vākya āśrayaṇe tyakta prāmāṇya svīkāraḥ  svīkṛta aprāmāṇya tyāgaḥ ca iti ekasmin yava vākye catvāraḥ doṣāḥ bhavanti
translated: If barley is sometimes accepted, it would abandon the accepted validity.🔽It would abandon the accepted invalidity. Thus, in the barley statement alone there are four faults.

original: evaṃ vrīhivākyepi catvāro doṣā ityevaṃ duṣṭavikalpaparihārāya bhinnaśākhaśrutyorapyekavākyatā jaiminisaṃmatetyāhataduktamiti /
analyzed: evam vrīhi vākye api catvāraḥ doṣāḥ iti evam duṣṭa vikalpa parihārāya bhinna śākhā śrutyoḥ api ekavākya tā jaimini saṃmatā iti āha tat uktam iti
translated: Similarly, there are four faults in the rice statement. Thus, to avoid the tainted option, Jaimini accepts that even the Vedic texts from different branches form a single sentence. He says: That has been stated.

analyzed: jyotiṣṭoma prakaraṇe dīkṣitaḥ na juhoti
translated: In the context of the Jyotiṣṭoma, it is heard: The uninitiated does not offer the oblation.

original: iti śrutaṃ 'yāvajjīvamagnihotraṃ juhuyāt'iti cānyatra śrutaṃ tatra yadi nadīkṣitavākyaṃ homapratiṣedhakaṃ syāttadā kratvarthatvānniṣedho 'nuṣṭheyaḥ /
analyzed: iti śrutam yāvajjīvam agnihotram juhuyāt iti ca anyatra śrutam tatra yadi na dīkṣita vākyam homa pratiṣedhakam syāt tadā kratu artha tvāt niṣedhaḥ nuṣṭheyaḥ
translated: And elsewhere it is heard: One should offer the Agnihotra as long as one lives. There, if the sentence about the uninitiated were to prohibit the oblation, then the prohibition would have to be performed because it serves the purpose of the sacrifice.

original: yāvajjīvavidhinā homo vānuṣṭheya iti vikalpaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yāvat jīva vidhinā homaḥ vā anuṣṭheyaḥ iti vikalpaḥ syāt
translated: Or the oblation would have to be performed by the injunction to do so as long as one lives. Thus there would be an option.

analyzed: sa ca anyāyyaḥ
translated: And that is improper.

original: api tu yāvajjīvavākyaṃ prati nadīkṣitavākyasya śeṣatvānnakāra itaraparyudāsārthakaḥ syāddīkṣitānyalakṣakaḥ syāt /
analyzed: api tu yāvajjīva vākyam prati na dīkṣita vākyasya śeṣa tvāt nakāraḥ itara paryudāsa arthakaḥ syāt dīkṣita anya lakṣakaḥ syāt
translated: Rather, because the sentence about the uninitiated is a supplement to the sentence about as long as one lives, the word not would have the meaning of exclusion of the other, indicating something other than the initiated.

analyzed: na homa pratiṣedhakaḥ
translated: It is not a prohibition of the oblation.

analyzed: tasmāt adīkṣitaḥ yāvajjīvam juhuyāt iti eka vākya tā iti na dīkṣita adhikaraṇa siddhānta sūtra arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning of the Siddhānta Sūtra of the Adhikaraṇa on the uninitiated is: The uninitiated one should offer as long as he lives. Thus it forms a single sentence.

analyzed: atra bhagavat pādaiḥ sūtram eva paṭhitam
translated: Here, the revered Pādas have recited the Sūtra itself.

original: miśraistu paryudāsādhikaraṇasiddhāntasūtraṃ 'api tu vākyaśeṣaḥ syādanyāyyatvādvikalpasya vidhīnāmekadeśaḥ syāt'iti sthitamatrārthataḥ paṭhitamityuktaṃ
analyzed: miśraiḥ tu paryudāsa adhikaraṇa siddhānta sūtram api tu vākyaśeṣaḥ syāt anyāyya tvāt vikalpasya vidhīnām eka deśaḥ syāt iti sthitam atra arthataḥ paṭhitam iti uktam
translated: But the Mīśras have said that the Siddhānta Sūtra of the Paryudāsa Adhikaraṇa, But it would be a supplement, because an option is improper. It would be a part of the injunctions, has been recited here in substance.

analyzed: tat cintyam
translated: And that should be considered.

original: sūtrārthastu yajñamātre yeyajāmahe iti prayoktavyamiti śrutaṃ /
analyzed: sūtra arthaḥ tu yajña mātre ye yajāmahe iti prayoktavyam iti śrutam
translated: The meaning of the sutra is that it has been heard that the mantra yeyajāmahe should be used only in the main sacrifice.

analyzed: na anuyājeṣu yeyajāmaham karoti iti api śrutam
translated: It has also been heard that one does not use yeyajāmahe in the after-sacrifices.

original: tatra nakārasya niṣedhakatve 'pyatirātre ṣoḍaśigrahaṇāgrahaṇayorivānuyājeṣu yajñatvāviśeṣātprayoktavyaṃ niṣedhānna prayoktavyamiti vikalpaḥ
analyzed: tatra nakārasya niṣedhaka tve pi atirātre ṣoḍaśi grahaṇa agrahaṇayoḥ iva anuyājeṣu yajña tva aviśeṣāt prayoktavyam niṣedhāt na prayoktavyam iti vikalpaḥ
translated: There, even though the word na (not) has the sense of prohibition, just as in the case of taking or not taking the Ṣoḍaśi cup in the Atirātra sacrifice, it should be used in the after-sacrifices because of the non-difference of being a sacrifice, but it should not be used because of the prohibition. This is an option.

analyzed: tasya anyāyya tvāt yeyajāmaha vidheḥ eva na anuyāja vākyam eka deśaḥ syāt
translated: Because that is unreasonable, the injunction of yeyajāmahe itself should not be a part of the sentence about the after-sacrifices.

analyzed: paryudāsa vṛttyā vidhi vākya śeṣaḥ syāt iti yāvat
translated: It should be a remainder of the injunctive sentence by the operation of exclusion, that is all.

original: tathā cānuyājabhinneṣu yāgeṣu yeyajāmaha iti prayoktavyamityekavākyateti /
analyzed: tathā ca anuyāja bhinneṣu yāgeṣu yeyajāmahe iti prayoktavyam iti eka vākya tā iti
translated: And thus, it is a single sentence that yeyajāmahe should be used in sacrifices other than the after-sacrifices.

analyzed: varṇaka antaram āha athavā iti
translated: He states another view: Or rather...

analyzed: pūrvatravidhūnanam karma hāniḥ iti siddhavatkṛtyaḥ upāyana upasaṃhāraḥ uktaḥ
translated: In the previous case, shaking was treated as if it were well-known, and the conclusion about removal was stated by taking it as such.

analyzed: atra sā eva sādhyate iti bhedaḥ
translated: Here, that itself is being proven. This is the difference.

analyzed: ubhayatra lakṣaṇa asāmyāt saṃśayam āha kim iti
translated: Because of the similarity of the definition in both cases, he raises a doubt: What is...

original: vidhūnanasya hi phaladvayamaśvaromādiṣu dṛṣṭaṃ pūrvasvabhāvāt cyutiranyatra saṃkrāntiśceti /
analyzed: vidhūnanasya hi phala dvayam aśva roma ādiṣu dṛṣṭam pūrva svabhāvāt cyutiḥ anyatra saṃkrāntiḥ ca iti
translated: For shaking, two fruits are seen in horse hair and so on: falling away from the previous nature and transference to another.

analyzed: tatra saṃkrānti rūpa hāniḥ lakṣaṇīyā kiṃvā cyutiḥ iti saṃśaya arthaḥ
translated: The doubt is whether loss in the form of transference or falling away should be indicated there.

original: tatra vidhūnanaśabdasya kampanaṃ mukhyārtha iti tāvatsarvasaṃmatam /
analyzed: tatra vidhūnana śabdasya kampanam mukhya arthaḥ iti tāvat sarva saṃmatam
translated: To that, it is generally agreed that the primary meaning of the word 'shaking' is trembling.

analyzed: tat ca amūrtayoḥ puṇya pāpayoḥ na saṃbhavati
translated: And that is not possible for the incorporeal merit and demerit.

original: atastayoryaḥ svabhāvaḥ phaladātṛtvaśaktistataścālanaṃ vidyayā pratibandhāccyutiḥ sā lakṣaṇīyā na hāniramūrtayoranyatra saṃkrāntyayogādanyasāpekṣatvācceti
analyzed: atas tayoḥ yaḥ svabhāvaḥ phala dātṛ tva śaktiḥ tatas cālanam vidyayā pratibandhāt cyutiḥ sā lakṣaṇīyā na hāniḥ amūrtayoḥ anyatra saṃkrānti ayogāt anya sāpekṣa tvāt ca iti
translated: Therefore, the shaking of that nature, which is the power to give the fruit, and the falling away due to obstruction by knowledge, that should be indicated, not loss, because of the impossibility of transference elsewhere for the incorporeal, and because of dependence on another.
This is the meaning of the prima facie view.

analyzed: siddhānta yati hānau eva iti
translated: He concludes with 'loss alone'.

analyzed: yadi cyuti mātram lakṣyam tadā upayanti iti ananvitam syāt
translated: And if mere falling away is to be indicated, then 'they go' would be unconnected.

original: naca yatra dhunoterūpāyanaśabdasāṃnidhyaṃ tatra hānirlakṣyate na kevaladhunoterhāniścānyatra viduṣaḥ sevakādau tulyakarmasaṃkrāntiriti nāsaṃbhava
analyzed: na ca yatra dhunoteḥ ūpāyana śabda sāṃnidhyam tatra hāniḥ lakṣyate na kevala dhunoteḥ hāniḥ ca anyatra viduṣaḥ sevaka ādau tulya karma saṃkrāntiḥ iti na asaṃbhava
translated: And it cannot be said that where the word 'going' is present along with the form 'dhunoti', loss is indicated there, and loss by 'dhunoti' alone is elsewhere, and that there is transference of equal karma to the knower's servant etc.

analyzed: iti vācyam
translated: So it is not impossible.

original: kevaladhunoterapi mukhyārthāsaṃbhavenānyatra lakṣyatayā buddhisthahānilakṣaṇāyā eva yuktatvāditi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: kevala dhunoteḥ api mukhya artha asaṃbhavena anyatra lakṣya tayā buddhi stha hāni lakṣaṇāyāḥ eva yukta tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that it is proper to have the indication of loss, which is present in the mind, by 'dhunoti' alone, because of the impossibility of the primary meaning elsewhere.

original: upāyanasyāmukhyatvānna kvāpi hānilakṣaṇābījatvamiti śaṅkitvā puṇyapāpayoḥ phalataḥ svīkārātmakamupāyanaṃ hāniṃ vinānupapannaṃ sallakṣaṇānirṇāyakamiti
analyzed: upāyanasya amukhya tvāt na kvāpi hāni lakṣaṇa abīja tvam iti śaṅkitvā puṇya pāpayoḥ phalataḥ svīkāra ātmakam upāyanam hānim vinā anupapannam sat lakṣaṇā nirṇāyakam iti
translated: Fearing that since the giving up is not primary, it cannot be the seed of the definition of giving up anywhere, he says that the giving up, which is the acceptance of the fruits of merit and demerit, is not possible without giving up, and that it is not determinative of the definition.

analyzed: pariharati yadi api ityādinā
translated: He answers with Even though and so on.

original: yathānyatraśrutamaudumbaratvādikaṃ kuśādinirṇāyakaṃ tathedamupāyanaṃ vidhūnanasya hānatve niścāyakamityāhakvacidapīti /
analyzed: yathā anyatra śrutam audumbara tva ādikam kuśa ādi nirṇāyakam tathā idam upāyanam vidhūnanasya hāna tve niścāyakam iti āha kvacid api iti
translated: Just as the Udumbara nature etc., heard elsewhere, determines the Kusha etc., so this giving up determines the shaking to be giving up. He says even in some other case.

analyzed: vidhūnanam mukhyam kim iti nā ucyate
translated: Why is the shaking not said to be primary?

analyzed: tatra aha na ca iti
translated: There he says But not.

original: tathāpi hānaṃ kathaṃ lakṣyata ityāśaṅkya mukhyasaṃbandhādityāhaaśvaśceti /
analyzed: tathā api hānam katham lakṣyate iti āśaṅkya mukhya saṃbandhāt iti āha aśvaḥ ca iti
translated: Even so, how is giving up defined? Fearing this, he says by the connection with the primary with the horse and so on.

original: anupapattisaṃbandhau lakṣaṇābījarūpāmuktvā lakṣakaṃ padaṃ nirdiśatiaśva iveti /
analyzed: anupapatti saṃbandhau lakṣaṇā bīja rūpām uktvā lakṣakam padam nirdiśati aśvaḥ iva iti
translated: Having stated the connection of non-applicability as the form of the seed of the definition, he points out the suggestive word with the horse and so on.

original: vidhūyeti padaṃ dṛṣṭānte hānaparyantaṃ saddārṣṭāntike 'pi hānalakṣakamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: vidhūya iti padam dṛṣṭānte hāna paryantam sat dārṣṭāntike hāna lakṣakam iti arthaḥ
translated: The word having shaken is suggestive of giving up in the example up to the end of giving up, and in the case in point also it is suggestive of giving up. This is the meaning.

original: yadvā hānavācakamevāstu naca dhūñ kampana iti dhātupāṭhavirodhastasyopalakṣaṇārthatvādityāhaaneketi /
analyzed: yat vā hāna vācakam evā astu na ca dhūm kampanaḥ iti dhātu pāṭha virodhaḥ tasya upalakṣaṇa artha tvāt iti āha aneka iti
translated: Or let it be just expressive of giving up. And there is no contradiction with the root text that Dhū means shaking, because it is for the purpose of indicating that. He says many and so on.

original: śākhāntarasthamupāyanaṃ vidhūnanasya hānatvaniścāyakamityatra jaiminisūtraṃ taduktamiti gṛhītapūrvaṃ vyākhyātamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: śākhā antara stham upāyanam vidhūnanasya hāna tva niścāyakam iti atra jaimini sūtram tat uktam iti gṛhīta pūrvam vyākhyātam iti arthaḥ
translated: The Jaimini Sutra, which states that the bringing in of the other branch confirms the fact of shaking being a means of destruction, has been accepted and explained before. This is the meaning.

original: evaṃ vidhṛnanasya hānitvisiddheḥ kevalahānāvupāyanopasaṃhāra iti siddham ////
analyzed: evam vidhṛnanasya hāni tvi siddheḥ kevala hānau upāyana upasaṃhāraḥ iti siddham
translated: Thus, since the fact of shaking being a means of destruction is established, it is established that the bringing in is for the sole purpose of destruction.🔽end

analyzed: e ns  start
translated: start

analyzed: sāṃparāye tartavya abhāvāt tathā hi anye  /
translated: In the next world, because there is nothing to be crossed, it is like this for others.

analyzed: saṃparāye anye
translated: In the next world, others.

analyzed: vyadhvani ardha mārge
translated: In the middle of the path, in the middle of the journey.

original: pūrvoktaṃ vidhūnanasya hānatvamupajīvya hānasya nadītaraṇānantaryaśruteraśvaiva romāṇi ityādau dehatyāgātprākkālatvaśruteśca saṃśayamāhatatkimiti
analyzed: pūrva uktam vidhūnanasya hāna tvam upajīvya hānasya nadī taraṇa ānantarya śruteḥ aśva eva romāṇi ityādau dehatyāgāt prāk kālatva śruteḥ ca saṃśayam āha tat kim iti
translated: Depending on the previously stated fact of shaking being a means of destruction, because of the statement that destruction is immediately followed by crossing the river, and because of the statement that the hair falls off before the body is abandoned in the case of just as the hair falls off, there is a doubt - what is that?

original: brahmalokamārgamadhye virajākhyāṃ nadīmatyeti tatsukṛtaduṣkṛte vidhūnute /🔽ityatra taditisarvanāmaśrutyāstenetyarthatayā saṃnihitanadītaraṇasya karmahānihetutvokterardhapathe karmakṣaya iti pūrvapakṣaḥ /
analyzed: brahma loka mārga madhye virajā ākhyām nadīm atyeti tad sukṛta duṣkṛte vidhūnute  iti atra tat iti sarvanāma śrutyāḥ tena iti arthatayā saṃnihita nadī taraṇasya karma hāni hetu tva ukteḥ ardha pathe karma kṣayaḥ iti pūrvapakṣaḥ
translated: In the middle of the path to the world of Brahman, he crosses the river called Viraja, and shakes off his good and bad deeds.🔽Here, because of the statement that the crossing of the river, which is referred to by the pronoun that, is the cause of the destruction of karma, the prima facie view is that karma is destroyed in the middle of the path.

analyzed: tatra vidyāyāḥ karma kṣaya hetu tva asiddheḥ pūrvapakṣe
translated: In that case, because of the non-establishment of knowledge as the cause of the destruction of karma, in the prima facie view,

analyzed: siddhānte tad siddhiḥ iti matvā siddhāntayati sāṃparāyaḥ iti
translated: Thinking that it is established in the Siddhānta, he concludes with 'sāṃparāyikam'.

analyzed: maraṇāt prāk iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is 'before death'.

original: saṃparetasya mṛtasya kañcitkālaṃ karmasattve phalābhāvāddevayānamārgapraveśāyogāccādāveva kṣaya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: saṃparetasya mṛtasya kañcid kālam karma sattve phala abhāvāt deva yāna mārga praveśa ayogāt ca ādau eva kṣayaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is destruction at the very beginning, because for one who has departed, who has died, there is no effect even if the action exists for some time, and because he is not fit to enter the path of the gods.

analyzed: kṣaya hetoḥ vidyāyāḥ madhye mārgam asattvāt ca iti āha vidyā viruddha iti
translated: He says that there is destruction due to the cause of knowledge, because it does not exist in the middle of the path, and because it is opposed to knowledge.

analyzed: nadī taraṇa anantara pāṭhaḥ tu bādhyaḥ
translated: But the recitation after crossing the river is to be contradicted.

analyzed: artha virodhāt iti āha tasmāt iti

analyzed: ūrdhvaretaḥ śabditam pārivrājyam anuṣṭheyam na vā iti māna bhrānti mūla tvābhyām saṃdehe bhrānti mūla tvāt na anuṣṭheyam iti āha trayaḥ iti
translated: In doubt as to whether the wandering life, called ‘having the upward-moving semen’, should be practised or not, because of its being based on valid knowledge or error, he says ‘Three’, that it should not be practised because it is based on error.

analyzed: āśramāṇām avāntarabheda apekṣayā bahuvacanam
translated: The plural is used with reference to the subdivisions of the stages of life.

analyzed: tathā ca kāṇvāyana smṛtiḥ arthataḥ
translated: And thus the Kāṇvākṣa Smṛti is referred to in meaning.

analyzed: gāyatraḥ brāhmaḥ prājāpatyaḥ bṛhan iti brahmacārī caturvidhaḥ
translated: The Brahmachārin is of four kinds, viz., Gāyatrī, Brāhma, Prājāpatya, and Bṛhat.

analyzed: tatra upanayanāt ūrdhvam yaḥ tri rātram a kṣāra a lavaṇa āśī gāyatrīm adhīte sa gāyatraḥ
translated: Among them, one who, after the initiation, eats for three nights food without salt and pungent substances and studies the Gāyatrī, is Gāyatrī.

original: yastu vedasya grahaṇāntaṃ brahmacaryaṃ carati sa brāhmaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu vedasya grahaṇa antam brahmacaryam carati sa brāhmaḥ
translated: One who observes celibacy until the completion of the Veda study is Brāhma.

analyzed: ṛtu kāle sva dāra gāmī nityam para strī vimukhaḥ prājāpatyaḥ
translated: One who goes to his own wife during the menstrual period and is always averse to other women is Prājāpatya.

analyzed: saṃvatsaram veda vrata kṛt vaṭuḥ vā prājāpatyaḥ
translated: A boy who observes the Vedic vows for a year is also Prājāpatya.

analyzed: āmaraṇam guru kula vāsī naiṣṭhikaḥ bṛhan iti ucyate
translated: One who lives in the teacher's house until death and is a lifelong celibate is called Bṛhat.

original: gṛhastho 'pi caturvidhaḥ vārtāko yāyāvaraḥ śālīno ghorasaṃnyasikaśceti /
analyzed: gṛhasthaḥ u pi caturvidhaḥ vārtākaḥ yāyāvaraḥ śālīnaḥ ghorasaṃnyasikaḥ ca iti
translated: The householder is also of four kinds: Vārtaka, Yāyāvara, Śālīna, and Ghora-saṃnyāsika.

analyzed: tatra kṛṣi gorakṣa ādikayā vaiśya ādi vṛttyā jīvan ityādi kriyā paraḥ vārtāka vṛttiḥ
translated: Among them, one who lives by the occupation of a Vaiśya etc. such as agriculture, cattle rearing, etc., and is devoted to such activities as plowing etc., is of Vārtaka livelihood.

analyzed: yāyāvaraḥ tu a yācita vṛttiḥ yājana adhyāpana pratigraha vimukhaḥ
translated: The Yāyāvara, on the other hand, is of unasked-for livelihood, averse to officiating at sacrifices, teaching, and accepting gifts.

analyzed: śālīnaḥ tu ṣaṭkarma nirataḥ yājana ādi vṛttiḥ saṃcayī
translated: The Śālīna, however, is engaged in the six duties, has a livelihood from officiating at sacrifices etc., and accumulates wealth.

original: uddhṛtaparipūtābhiradbhiḥ kāryaṃ kurvanpratyahaṃ kṛtoñchavṛttirgrāmavāsī ghorasaṃnyasika ityucyate /
analyzed: uddhṛta paripūtābhiḥ adbhiḥ kāryam kurvan pratyaham kṛta uñcha vṛttiḥ grāma vāsī ghorasaṃnyasikaḥ iti ucyate
translated: One who performs his daily duties with water drawn from a well or a tank, and who lives in a village, is called a terrible renunciant.

analyzed: hiṃsā vimukha tvāt
translated: Because he is averse to violence.

original: vānaprastho 'pi caturvidhaḥ vaikhānasa audumbaro vālakhilyaḥ phenapaśceti /
analyzed: vānaprasthaḥ u pi caturvidhaḥ vaikhānasaḥ audumbaraḥ vālakhilyaḥ phenapaḥ ca iti
translated: And the forest-dweller is also of four kinds: Vaikhānasa, Audumbara, Vālakhilya, and Phenapa.

analyzed: tatra akṛṣṭapacya oṣadhībhiḥ grāma bahiṣkṛtābhiḥ agnihotra ādi kurvan vaikhānasaḥ ucyate
translated: Among them, one who performs the Agnihotra and other rites with unploughed and uncultivated herbs outside the village is called Vaikhānasa.

original: yastu prātaruthāya yāṃ diśaṃ paśyati tatratyaudumbarabadarīnīvāraśyāmākaiḥ karmaparaḥ sa audumbaraḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu prātar uthāya yām diśam paśyati tatratya audumbara badarī nīvāra śyāmākaiḥ karma paraḥ saḥ audumbaraḥ
translated: But one who, having risen in the morning, looks in the direction where there are Udumbara and Badari trees, and who is devoted to rites with Nīvāra and Śyāmāka grains, is Audumbara.

original: yastu jaṭāvalkaladhārī aṣṭau prātasānvṛttyupārjanaṃ kṛtvā cāturmāsye saṃgṛhītāśī kārtikyāṃ saṃgṛhītapuṣpaphalatyāgī sa vālakhilyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu jaṭā valkala dhārī aṣṭau prātasa anvṛtti upārjanam kṛtvā cāturmāsye saṃgṛhīta āśī kārtikyām saṃgṛhīta puṣpa phala tyāgī sa vālakhilyaḥ
translated: But one who wears matted hair and bark garments, who having earned his livelihood by eight morning collections, eats the collected food in the four months, and gives up the collected flowers and fruits in the month of Kārttika, is Vālakhilya.

original: phenapāstu śīrṇaparṇaphalavṛttayo yatra kvacidvasantaḥ karmaparā iti /
analyzed: phenapāḥ tu śīrṇa parṇa phala vṛttayaḥ yatra kvacid vasantaḥ karma parāḥ iti
translated: But Phenapas live on the fruits of fallen leaves, dwelling anywhere, and are devoted to rites.

original: tathā parivrājākāścaturvidhāḥ kuṭīcakā bahūdakā haṃsāḥ paramahaṃsāśceti /
analyzed: tathā parivrājākāḥ caturvidhāḥ kuṭīcakāḥ bahūdakāḥ haṃsāḥ paramahaṃsāḥ ca iti
translated: Similarly, the wandering renunciants are of four kinds: Kuṭīcakas, Bahūdakas, Haṃsas, and Paramahaṃsas.

analyzed: tatra sva putra gṛhe bhikṣām carantaḥ tridaṇḍinaḥ kuṭīcakāḥ
translated: There, the Tridaṇḍins who wander about begging alms in the houses of their own sons are the Kuṭīcakas.

original: bahūdakāstu tridaṇḍinaḥ śikyajalapavitrapādukāsanaśikhāyajñopavītakaupīnakāṣāyaveṣadhārāstīrthānyaṭanto bhaikṣaṃ caranta ātmānaṃ prārthayante
analyzed: bahūdakāḥ tu tridaṇḍinaḥ śikya jala pavitra pādukā āsana śikhā yajñopavīta kaupīna kāṣāya veṣa dhārāḥ tīrthāni aṭantaḥ bhaikṣam carantaḥ ātmānam prārthayante
translated: The Bahūdakas, however, who are Tridaṇḍins, who wear a sling, a water-pot, a sacred thread, shoes, a seat, a tuft of hair, a sacred thread, a loincloth, and a saffron robe, who wander about in holy places, who beg alms, and who pray to the Self,

original: haṃsāstu ekadaṇḍinaḥ śikhāvarjaṃ yajñopavītadharāḥ śikyakamaṇḍalupāṇayaḥ grāmaikarātravāsinaḥ kṛcchracāndrāyaṇaparāḥ /
analyzed: haṃsāḥ tu eka daṇḍinaḥ śikhā varjam yajñopavīta dharāḥ śikya kamaṇḍalu pāṇayaḥ grāma eka rātra vāsinaḥ kṛcchra cāndrāyaṇa parāḥ
translated: The Haṃsas, however, who are Ekadaṇḍins, who wear a sacred thread except for a tuft of hair, who carry a sling and a water-pot in their hands, who live in a village for one night, who are devoted to Kṛcchra and Cāndrāyaṇa penances,

original: paramahaṃsāstvekadaṇḍadharā muṇḍā ayajñopavītinaḥ tyaktasarvakarmāṇa ātmaniṣṭhā iti /
analyzed: paramahaṃsāḥ tu eka daṇḍa dharāḥ muṇḍāḥ a yajña upavītinaḥ tyakta sarva karmāṇaḥ ātma niṣṭhāḥ iti
translated: The Paramahaṃsas, however, who carry one staff, who are shaven, who do not wear a sacred thread, who have renounced all actions, who are devoted to the Self.

original: atra pūrvapakṣe saṃnyāsābhāvāñjñānasya svatantraphalatvāsiddhiḥ siddhānte tadbhāvāttatsiddhiriti phalabhedaḥ /
analyzed: atra pūrvapakṣe saṃnyāsa abhāvāt jñānasya svatantra phalatva asiddhiḥ siddhānte tad bhāvāt tad siddhiḥ iti phala bhedaḥ
translated: Here, in the prima facie view, due to the absence of renunciation, the independence of knowledge as a fruit is not established. In the conclusion, due to its existence, its establishment is the difference in fruits.

original: skandhā āśramāḥ ātmānaṃ śarīramācāryasya kule gṛhe karśayannaiṣṭhika ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: skandhāḥ āśramāḥ ātmānam śarīram ācāryasya kule gṛhe karśayan naiṣṭhikaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The stages are the parts. The meaning is that one who emaciates his body, his Self, in the house of the teacher's family is a life-long student.

original: skandhaśrutāvāśramā na vidhīyante kintu brahmasaṃsthatāsturthamanūdyanta ityukte śaṅkatenanu parāmarśe 'pīti /
analyzed: skandha śrutau āśramāḥ na vidhīyante kintu brahma saṃstha tāḥ turtham anūdyante iti ukte śaṅkate nanu parāmarśe pi iti
translated: In the hearing of the aggregates, the stages of life are not enjoined, but rather the state of being established in Brahman is mentioned as the fourth. When this is said, he doubts: But even in the reference,

analyzed: anuvāda apekṣita purovādāt pratītim aṅgīkaroti satyam iti
translated: He accepts the understanding from the prior statement required by the restatement, saying True.

original: pratyakṣā skandhaśrutireva purovādo 'stu nānuvāda ityata āhasmṛtīti /
analyzed: pratyakṣā skandha śrutiḥ eva purovādaḥ astu na anuvādaḥ iti atas āha smṛti iti
translated: Let the direct hearing of the aggregates itself be the prior statement, not a restatement. To this he says memory.

analyzed: tayoḥ api iyam eva śrutiḥ mūlam astu
translated: Let that very Vedic text be the basis for those two also.

analyzed: kḷpta śrutau vidhi mātra kalpanā lāghavāt
translated: Because in the established Vedic text, the assumption of the injunction alone is simpler.

original: asyā anuvādatve tu mūlatvena sāgnikānagnikāśramaśrutistatra vidhiśceti dvayakalpanāgauravādityata āhaataśceti /🔽smārtatvādāśramāḥ pratyakṣayāvajjīvakarmavidhiśrutyaviruddhā grāhyāḥ /🔽viruddhāstvanagnikāśramā upekṣyāḥ karmānadhikṛtairandhādibhirvā anuṣṭheyā ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: asyāḥ anuvāda tve tu mūla tvena sa agnika anagnika āśrama śrutiḥ tatra vidhiḥ ca iti dvaya kalpanā gauravāt iti atas āha atas ca iti  smārta tvāt āśramāḥ pratyakṣa yāvajjīva karma vidhi śruti aviruddhāḥ grāhyāḥ  viruddhāḥ tu anagnika āśramāḥ upekṣyāḥ karma anadhikṛtaiḥ andha ādibhiḥ vā anuṣṭheyāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: But if this is a restatement, then the assumption of two things is cumbersome: the Vedic text about the stages of life with and without fire as the basis, and the injunction there. To this he says And for this reason.🔽Because they are based on smrti, the stages of life that are not contradicted by the directly perceived Vedic injunctions to perform duties throughout life should be accepted.🔽But those stages of life without fire are to be disregarded, or to be practiced by those not entitled to perform rituals, such as the blind, etc. This is the meaning.

analyzed: yāvat jīva śruti virodhāt lāghavam tyājyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the simplicity is to be abandoned because of the contradiction with the Vedic injunctions to perform duties throughout life.

analyzed: skandha śrutau anuvādya tva aviśeṣāt gārhasthya vat itareṣām anuṣṭheya tvam āśaṅkya tasya śrauta tvāt anuṣṭhānam
translated: Fearing that, like the householder's stage, the other stages would be to be performed because of the non-distinction of being praised in the hearing of the aggregates, the performance is

analyzed: na itareṣām aśrauta tvāt atas brahma saṃstha tā stuti param idam skandha vākyam iti āha nanu ityādinā
translated: because of their being heard, not of the others because of their not being heard. Therefore, this statement about the aggregates is for the purpose of praising the state of being established in Brahman. He says But and so on.

analyzed: tantum saṃtatim
translated: Tantu means continuity.

original: tathā ye ceti /🔽te 'rciṣamabhisaṃbhavantīti vākyaśeṣādityarthaḥ /🔽skandhaśabdasya āśrameṣvarūḍhatvāccātra nāśramividhirityāhasaṃdigdhaṃ ceti /
analyzed: tathā ye ca iti  te rciṣam abhisaṃbhavanti iti vākya śeṣāt iti arthaḥ  skandha śabdasya āśrameṣu arūḍha tvāt ca atra na āśrami vidhiḥ iti āha saṃdigdham ca iti
translated: Similarly, those who means those who are established in the state of being established in Brahman.🔽The meaning is that it is from the remainder of the sentence They attain the light.🔽And because the word aggregate is not well-established in the stages, the injunction of the stages is not here. He says And it is doubtful and so on.

analyzed: tarhi pravrajanti iti āśrama vidhiḥ īti atas āha tathā etam iti
translated: Then, if it is an injunction of the stage by the word they go forth, he says In that way, this and so on.

original: ātmaloko mahīyān yadarthamaśakyāṃ pravrajyāmapi kurvantīti stutirvartamānāpadeśādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: ātma lokaḥ mahīyān yad artham aśakyām pravrajyām api kurvanti iti stutiḥ vartamāna apadeśāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The self-world is greater, for the sake of which they undertake even the impossible going forth. The meaning is that it is praise from the statement of the present.

analyzed: saṃprati pūrvapakṣam ākṣipya iyam śrutiḥ na asti iti kṛtvā cintyate iti āha nanu ityādinā 🔽e ns 🔽start 🔽anuṣṭheyam bādarāyaṇaḥ sāmya śruteḥ  /
translated: Now, having objected to the prima facie view that this scripture does not exist, it is considered. He says But and so on.

translated: In the hearing of the Skandhas, the other Ashramas, enjoined in other scriptures, are referred to, because they are to be referred to in this statement, like the householder's life. He concludes thus: The Ashramas are to be performed.

analyzed: anuvādasya kvacid vidhi pūrvaka tve dṛṣṭāntam āha yathā ca iti
translated: He gives an example of the reference being preceded by an injunction somewhere, thus: Just as...

original: nivītaṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ prācīnāvītaṃ pitṛṇāmupavītaṃ devānāmiti vākye daive karmaṇyupavītaṃ vidhīyate /
analyzed: nivītam manuṣyāṇām prācīnāvītam pitṛṇām upavītam devānām iti vākye daive karmaṇi upavītam vidhīyate
translated: In the statement The Nivita is for humans, the Prachinavita is for the ancestors, and the Upavita is for the gods, the Upavita is enjoined for the divine rite.

analyzed: tad stutaye dvayam anūdyate
translated: For the praise of that, the other two are referred to.

original: mānuṣakriyāsu dehārdhavastrabandhanākhyanivītasya saukaryārtatayā prāptatvāt pitrye karmaṇi prācīnāvītasyāpi vidhyantaraprāptatvādityarthaḥ
analyzed: mānuṣa kriyāsu deha ardha vastra bandhana ākhya nivītasya saukarya ārta tayā prāpta tvāt pitrye karmaṇi prācīnāvītasya api vidhi antara prāpta tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The Nivita, which is a kind of cloth-tying on the body, is obtained as easy to perform in human actions; and the Prachinavita is also obtained by another injunction in the ancestral rite. This is the meaning.

analyzed: vākya antare ca sākṣāt eva pārivrājya vidhiḥ vidheyaiḥ sāhityāt iti āha tathā etam eva iti
translated: And in another statement, the renunciation is directly enjoined by the connection with what is to be performed. He says thus: Just this...

analyzed: asya iti pārivrājya uktiḥ

analyzed: vidheya veda anuvacana ādi sāhityāt pārivrājyasya vidheya tā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that renunciation is to be performed because of its connection with what is to be performed, such as the recitation of the Vedas.

analyzed: vākya antare sāmya śrutim āha ya ca iti

analyzed: asya iti vānaprastha uktiḥ
translated: This refers to the mention of the forest-dweller.

analyzed: vidheya pañcāgni vidyayā tānaprasthasya saha uktyā tat api vidheyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that by the injunction of the five fires, which is to be done, and by the statement of the three, that is also to be done.

analyzed: utpatti bhinnāḥ iti

translated: It has been said that the stages of life are to be performed by assuming another injunction, accepting that the mention of the skandhas is a restatement.

analyzed: idānīm vidhi tvam tasyāḥ eva kalpyam lāghavāt iti āha vidhiḥ vā iti
translated: Now he says Or the injunction that its very injunction should be assumed, because of simplicity.

analyzed: yāvat jīva ādi śruteḥ avirakta viṣaya tvāt na lāghava bādhaka tvam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the mention of as long as one lives etc. is not contradicted by simplicity, because it refers to one who is not detached.

analyzed: alpa phala tvena āśrama traya nindayā brahma saṃstha tā stuti param ekam idam vākyam bhāti
translated: This single statement shines as praising the state of being established in Brahman by criticizing the three stages of life as having little fruit.

analyzed: tatra āśrama vidhi catuṣṭayam ayuktam iti śaṅkate nanu iti

analyzed: āśramāṇām vidhi antara prāpti abhāvāt anuvāda ayogāt

analyzed: stuti lakṣaṇa adoṣāt ca varam vispaṣṭa āśrama vidhi bheda kalpanam apūrva tvāt iti āha satyam ityādinā
translated: And because of the faults of the definition of praise, it is better to assume the difference in the injunctions of the stages of life, which are clearly stated, because they are new. Thus he says with 'satya' etc.

analyzed: pratīta eka vākya tva bhaṅgena bheda kalpane dṛṣṭāntam āha dhāraṇa vat iti

analyzed: mahāpitṛyajñe preta agnihotre ca sruci prakṣiptam haviḥ āhavanīyam prati yadā nīyate

translated: the holding below of that oblation, which is enjoined by the statement 'he should follow it holding a kindling wood below', is subordinate to that.

original: hītyasyaikavākyatvabhāne 'pi daive home srugdaṇḍopari samiddhāraṇe vidhirevāpūrvatvāditi
analyzed: hi iti asya eka vākya tva bhāne daive home sruc daṇḍa upari samidh dhāraṇe vidhiḥ eva apūrva tvāt iti
translated: Even when the unity of the sentence with 'he should follow it' is understood, the injunction of holding the kindling wood above the handle of the ladle in the divine offering is a new injunction, and

analyzed: evam catvāraḥ āśramāḥ vidhīyante iti pakṣaḥ uktaḥ

translated: Now, he states another view that only the stage of wandering mendicancy is enjoined by the restatement of the three stages of life, with 'yadaapi' etc.

analyzed: dṛśyate ca vilambaḥ atas śravaṇa ādeḥ vidyā hetu tvam asiddham iti pūrvapakṣe phalam
translated: And delay is seen. Therefore, the fact that hearing etc. are the causes of knowledge is not established. This is the result in the prima facie view.

original: pratibandhakavaśādvilambe 'pi hetutvasiddhiriti siddhānte phalaṃ matvā citrādivadaniyataphalaṃ śravaṇādikamiti siddhāntayatievamiti /
analyzed: pratibandhaka vaśāt vilambe pi hetu tva siddhiḥ iti siddhānte phalam matvā citra ādi vat aniyata phalam śravaṇa ādikam iti siddhāntayati evam iti
translated: The result in the established conclusion is that even when there is delay due to the power of obstacles, the fact that they are causes is established. Considering this, he establishes the conclusion that hearing etc. have a definite result like painting etc.

original: nanu prārabdhakarmaviśeṣeṇa śravaṇādiphalapratibandhaḥ kimiti kriyate śravaṇādinaiva karmavipākapratibandhaḥ kiṃ na syādityata āhaupasthitavipākatvaṃ
analyzed: nanu prārabdha karma viśeṣeṇa śravaṇa ādi phala pratibandhaḥ kim iti kriyate śravaṇa ādinā eva karma vipāka pratibandhaḥ kim na syāt iti atas āha aupasthita vipāka tvam
translated: Now, why is the result of hearing etc. obstructed by a particular karma that has begun? Why should not the ripening of karma itself be obstructed by hearing etc.? To this he says:

analyzed: ca iti
translated: The fact of being ready to ripen.

analyzed: deśa ādi mahimnā karmāṇi vipacyante iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that karmas ripen by the greatness of place etc.

analyzed: tena śravaṇa ādikam eva kim iti na vipacyante
translated: Then why do not hearing etc. themselves ripen?

analyzed: tatra āha yāni ca iti
translated: To this he says: those which.
Ripening means being the cause of being ready to ripen.

analyzed: nanu tarhi śravaṇa ādi vipācaka deśa ādikam kīdṛśam iti atas āha śāstram api iti
translated: But then, what is the ripening place etc. of hearing etc.? To this he says: The scriptures also.

analyzed: phala balāt deśa ādi jñānam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the knowledge of place etc. is due to the power of the result.

original: tathāpi karmaṇaiva śravaṇādipratibandho na vaiparītyamityatra ko hetustamāhasādhaneti /
analyzed: tathā api karmaṇā eva śravaṇa ādi pratibandhaḥ na vaiparītyam iti atra kaḥ hetuḥ tam āha sādhana iti
translated: Even so, the obstruction to hearing etc. is only by karma, not the opposite. What is the reason for this? He says: The means etc.

analyzed: pratibandhaka tva śaktiḥ api phala balāt jñātavyā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the power of obstruction should also be known due to the power of the result.

analyzed: pratibandhaka sadbhāve śrautam smārtam ca liṅgam āha tathā ca ityādinā
translated: In the case of the existence of the obstruction, he states the Vedic and Smārta indications with the words Thus indeed etc.

analyzed: śṛṇvantaḥ pi na vidyuḥ iti ukteḥ pratibandha siddhiḥ
translated: The establishment of the obstruction is due to the statement Even though they hear, they do not know.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ yathāvat vaktā api āścaryaḥ adbhuta vat kaścid eva bhavati
translated: Even the one who speaks of the self as it is is a wonder, like a marvel.

analyzed: tiṣṭhatu labdhā sākṣātkāravān  parokṣataḥ jñātā api āścaryaḥ
translated: Let alone the one who has attained direct realization.🔽Even the one who knows by inference is a wonder.

analyzed: kuśalena ācāryeṇa anuśiṣṭaḥ api iti arthaḥ 🔽e ns 🔽start 🔽evam mukti phala aniyamaḥ tad avasthā avadhṛteḥ tad avasthā avadhṛteḥ
translated: The meaning is: even though instructed by a skilled teacher.

original: asati prārabdhakarmapratibandhe śravaṇādinehaiva vidyodayaḥ yajñādibhiḥ saṃcitapāpapratibandhasya nirastatvāt /🔽sati tu bhogena tannirāsādamutreti vidyāyā aihikāmuṣmikatvaviśeṣaniyama uktastadvatphale
analyzed: asati prārabdha karma pratibandhe śravaṇa ādinā iha eva vidyā udayaḥ yajña ādibhiḥ saṃcita pāpa pratibandhasya nirasta tvāt  sati tu bhogena tad nirāsāt amutrā iti vidyāyāḥ aihika āmuṣmika tva viśeṣa niyamaḥ uktaḥ tadvat phale
translated: When there is no obstruction of the prārabdha karma, the manifestation of knowledge occurs in this very life through hearing etc., because the obstruction caused by the sins accumulated through sacrifices etc. has been removed.

analyzed: pi mokṣe kaścid utkarṣa ādi viśeṣaḥ syāt iti atas āha evam mukti phala aniyamaḥ tad avasthā avadhṛteḥ tad avasthā avadhṛteḥ
translated: But when there is [such an obstruction], it occurs in the next life through the removal of that by experience. Thus, it is said that there is a specific rule that the knowledge is either in this life or the next life, and similarly, there may be some special excellence etc. in the fruit of knowledge, which is liberation. To this, he says: Thus, there is no restriction on the fruit of liberation, because it is determined by that state, because it is determined by that state.

analyzed: muktiḥ atra viṣayaḥ
translated: Liberation is the topic here.

original: tasyāṃ vidyāvadviśeṣaniyamo 'sti na veti phalasyobhayathāsaṃbhavātsaṃśaye pūrvapakṣamāhayatheti /
analyzed: tasyām vidyā vat viśeṣa niyamaḥ sti na vā iti phalasya ubhayathā asaṃbhavāt saṃśaye pūrvapakṣam āha yathā iti
translated: Is there a specific rule regarding it, as in the case of knowledge, or not? Since the fruit is possible in both ways, there is a doubt. The prima facie view is stated thus: Just as....

analyzed: muktiḥ sa viśeṣā  phala tvāt vidyā vadataḥ karma sādhyā muktiḥ iti phalam
translated: Liberation is with special qualities.🔽The conclusion is that liberation is to be accomplished by action, because it is a fruit, like knowledge.

analyzed: siddhānte tu nirviśeṣa tva avadhāraṇa śruti bādhitam anumānam atas jñāna eka vyaṅgyā muktiḥ iti phalam
translated: But in the established conclusion, inference is contradicted by the Vedic text determining the absence of special qualities. Therefore, the conclusion is that liberation is manifested solely by knowledge.

original: kiñca śravaṇāditāratamyādvidyāyāṃ kañcidatiśayamaṅgīkṛtya vidyālabhyamuktau nātiśaya ityāhaapica vidyāsādhanamiti /
analyzed: kiñca śravaṇa ādi tāratamyāt vidyāyām kañcid atiśayam aṅgīkṛtya vidyā labhya muktau na atiśayaḥ iti āha api ca vidyā sādhanam iti
translated: Moreover, accepting some superiority in knowledge due to the gradation of hearing etc., he says that there is no superiority in the liberation attainable through knowledge.

analyzed: nanu brahmaṇaḥ nitya siddha tvāt avidyā nivṛtteḥ ca anyatve dvaita āpatteḥ
translated: But since Brahman is eternally existent, and since the cessation of ignorance is different from it, duality would result.

analyzed: ananyatve ca asādhya tva ādikam vidyā phalam iti atas āha tat hi iti
translated: And if it is not different, then the fruit of knowledge would be inexpressibility etc. To this he says: That is the fruit.

original: vidyayābhivyaktatvena brahmānanda eva mukhyaphalamabhivyaktiravidyānivṛttirānandasvarūpasphūrtipratibandhakābhāvatayā vidyayā sādhyate sā cānirvācyeti
analyzed: vidyayā abhivyakta tvena brahma ānandaḥ eva mukhya phalam abhivyaktiḥ avidyā nivṛttiḥ ānanda svarūpa sphūrti pratibandhaka abhāvatayā vidyayā sādhyate sā ca anirvācyā iti
translated: Brahman's bliss itself is the primary fruit, manifested by knowledge. Manifestation, the cessation of ignorance, is accomplished by knowledge as the absence of the obstruction to the manifestation of the nature of bliss. And that is inexpressible.

analyzed: na dvaita āpattiḥ
translated: So there is no duality.

analyzed: anye tu sā brahma ananyā iti āhuḥ
translated: But others say that it is not different from Brahman.

analyzed: naca sādhya tva anupapatteḥ tatra vidyā vaiyarthyam iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that knowledge is useless there because it cannot be accomplished.

analyzed: yad abhāve yad abhāvaḥ tat tat sādhyam iti jñānāt sarvaḥ lokaḥ pravartate
translated: For all people act on the knowledge that the absence of something is to be accomplished by that.

analyzed: yathā ca vidyāyāḥ abhāve brahma svarūpa mukteḥ abhāvaḥ nartha rūpā avidyā eva asti
translated: And just as the absence of Brahman's nature, liberation, would be mere ignorance, which is of the nature of non-existence, in the absence of knowledge,

analyzed: asyāḥ avidyāyāḥ eva muktiḥ na asti iti vyavahāra viṣaya tvena mukti abhāva tvāt
translated: Because this ignorance is the subject of the notion that it has no liberation, i.e., because it is the cause of the absence of liberation.

analyzed: tathā ca vidyām vinā muktiḥ nā asti iti niścayāt vidyām upādatte
translated: And thus, from the certainty that there is no liberation without knowledge, he takes up knowledge.

analyzed: vidyā udaye ca svatas siddha nitya nivṛtta anartha sva prakāśa brahma ānanda ātman avatiṣṭhate iti anavadyam
translated: And when knowledge arises, he abides in the self, which is Brahman, whose bliss is self-luminous, whose evil is eternally and naturally removed. Thus there is no fault.

analyzed: saṃprati vidyāyām atiśaya aṅgīkāra tyajati na ca iti
translated: Now he abandons the acceptance of the superiority of knowledge, saying not so.

analyzed: eka rūpe viṣaye pramāyām tāratamya anupapatteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in an object of one form, the gradation of valid knowledge is not possible.

original: kathaṃ tarhi pūrvādhikaraṇe vidyāyā viśeṣa uktaḥ /
analyzed: katham tarhi pūrva adhikaraṇe vidyāyāḥ viśeṣaḥ uktaḥ
translated: Then how is the distinction of knowledge stated in the previous section?

analyzed: tatra āha tasmāt iti
translated: There he says therefore.

original: satyāmapi sāmagryāṃ jñāne vilamba ukto na tāratamyamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: satyām api sāmagryām jñāne vilambaḥ uktaḥ na tāratamyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even when the means are present, delay in knowledge is stated, not gradation.

original: tarhi satyapi jñāne muktau vilambaḥ kiṃ na syādityata āhanatviti /
analyzed: tarhi sati api jñāne muktau vilambaḥ kim na syāt iti atas āha natu iti
translated: Then, even when there is knowledge, why should there not be delay in liberation? To this he says not so.

original: vāyvādipratibandhāddipotpattivilambe 'pyutpanne tamonivṛttivilambādarśanātsati jñāne nājñānanivṛttau vilamba iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: vāyu ādi pratibandhāt dipa utpatti vilambe pi utpanne tamaḥ nivṛtti vilamba adarśanāt sati jñāne na ajñāna nivṛttau vilambaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Even when there is delay in the arising of a lamp due to obstruction by air etc., since the removal of darkness is not seen to be delayed when it has arisen, there is no delay in the removal of ignorance when there is knowledge. This is the idea.

original: kiñca karmaṇāmupāsanānāṃ ca guṇabhedena tāratamyātphalatāratamyaṃ yuktam /
analyzed: kiñca karmaṇām upāsanānām ca guṇa bhedena tāratamyāt phala tāratamyam yuktam
translated: Moreover, since the results of actions and meditations vary according to the difference in their qualities, it is proper that there should be a gradation in their results.

analyzed: nirguṇa vidyāyāḥ tu eka rūpa tvāt tad phala aikarūpyam iti āha vidyā bheda ityādinā
translated: But in the case of the knowledge of the attributeless Brahman, the result is of one uniform kind, because the knowledge itself is of one uniform kind. This is what is said by the words beginning with 'vidyābheda' (in the commentary).

analyzed: smṛtau kasyacid nirguṇa vidaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: In the Smṛti, the word 'kasya cit' means 'of some one who knows Brahman as attributeless'.

analyzed: tasmāt vidyā sama kālā eva muktiḥ iti siddham
translated: Therefore, it is established that liberation is simultaneous with knowledge.

original: END / / /🔽iti śrīmatparamahaṃsaparivrājakācāryaśrīgovindānandabhagavatkṛtau śārīrakavyākhyāyā bhāṣyaratnaprabhāṭīkāyāṃ tṛtīyasyādhyāyasya caturthaḥ pādaḥ🔽iti tṛtīyādhyāyasya nirguṇavidyāyā antaraṅgabahiraṅgasādhanavicārākhyaścaturthaḥ pādaḥ //
analyzed: e ns  iti śrīmat paramahaṃsa parivrājaka ācārya śrī govindānanda bhagavat kṛtau śārīraka vyākhyāyāḥ bhāṣya ratna prabhā ṭīkāyām tṛtīyasya adhyāyasya caturthaḥ pādaḥ  iti tṛtīya adhyāyasya nirguṇa vidyāyāḥ antaraṅga bahiraṅga sādhana vicāra ākhyaḥ caturthaḥ pādaḥ
translated: End.🔽Thus ends the fourth chapter of the commentary called Bhāṣyaratnaprabhā on the third chapter of the Śārīraka commentary written by the revered Godāṃnābhīpāda, the great-grandson of the revered Govindānanda, a teacher of the Śrīmat Paramahaṃsa Parivrājakācāryas.🔽Thus ends the fourth chapter named the examination of the internal and external means of the knowledge of the attributeless Brahman, of the third chapter of the Śārīraka commentary of Śaṃkara Bhagavatpāda.

analyzed: iti śrīmat brahmasūtra śāṅkara bhāṣye sādhana ākhyaḥ tṛtīyaḥ adhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the third chapter named the means of knowledge in the Śrīmadbrahmasūtraśaṃkarabhāṣya.
